Actually, this happened to me when guiding two noobs trough the install. I was typing down like five lines on how to partition, and just as I pressed enter they wrote to me: "Ok, I've made a /boot 100 mb, /home 15GB and a / partition. Is that OK?" and I really could not disagree.
Well, actually the one only made a 10GB home, but that's not really the point.

You don't need more than one / partition, however I recomend having a /boot and a /home aswell. If you ever want to try a different distro you can use the same kernel (in all but a few cases) and you keep user settings.
What is the boot one for?
That will keep your kernel safe (if and when you roll your own) between distro installations.
and could be just 100 megs? It'd be better having it before the ext3 one right?
100 mb is plenty. It doesn't matter where it is unless you are using old hardware. I always put /boot on /dev/sda1 (hd0,0)
Well, move what's in /boot now to ie. /boot.bacup and mount the new partition to /boot and move the stuff back.
Also remember to setup your /etc/fstab and your /boot/grub.conf and run grub to update the bootloader with the new location of the bootloader files.
